DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Visit Lithuania to Try to Mend Party Rift
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will travel to Lithuania in coming days to try to persuade the republic's defiant Communist Party to reaffirm its allegiance to the national party, officials say. When it declared itself independent on Dec. 20 the Lithuanian Communist Party created the first major crack in the political monopoly forged by Vladimir Lenin after the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. Gorbachev attacked the Lithuanian party leadership at a meeting of the Soviet party's Central Committee held Monday and Tuesday to consider the Lithuanian break with Moscow. He accused the Lithuanians of allowing themselves to become ``hostages to separatists.'' But, in a report published Tuesday in the party newspaper Pravda, he also urged ``maximum restraint'' to allow emotions to cool. The 250-member Central Committee unanimously approved the report. The committee decided to send Gorbachev and other top party officials to Lithuania ``to explain our position and at the same time to get a better sense of the situation there,'' Vadim A. Medvedev, a Politburo member and the party's chief ideologist, told a news conference afterward. Medvedev said some officials at the Central Committee meeting proposed ousting the Lithuanians from the national party or annulling the Lithuanian decision, but others pushed more moderate measures. All were united, however, in their disapproval of the Lithuanian move, Mededev said. ``Most agreed that this was a blow to perestroika,'' he said, referring to Gorbachev's program to restructure the Soviet economy and to a certain extent the political system. Medvedev said the trip to Lithuania would take place ``in not very many days'' and that the Central Committee will make a firm decision on the dispute in January. The Lithuanian Communist leader, Algirdas Brazauskas, said in an interview that the party officials' visit would be ``good and helpful,'' an editor at Lithuanian Radio said. Despite the postponement of a full decision, the Central Committee's stand as stated Tuesday refused to recognize the Lithuanian party's self-proclaimed independent status. ``No part of the Soviet Communist Party has the right to decide the question about its independent existence with its own program and rules, not taking into account the position of the Soviet Communist Party as a whole,'' Gorbachev said in the report approved by the plenum. ``And this means that the Communist Party of Lithuania was and remains a part of the united Soviet Communist Party.'' Gorbachev tried for several months to head off the Lithuanian split. At the Congress of People's Deputies meeting in Moscow on Saturday he lashed out at separatists: ``Today, to realize the right to self-determination through secession means to blow up the union, set the people against each other and sow conflict and blood and death.'' Gorbachev told the Central Committee meeting the Soviet government should consider the legal status of movements that are ``carrying out separatist activities and whipping up nationalist terror.'' He did not identify any such organizations, but in the context of the debate he likely was referring to Lithuania's people's front, known as Sajudis, and other groups pushing for independence from the Soviet Union. Medvedev said the fight against separatist groups would not involve the use of force by Moscow. ``We're against application of the military or other such methods,'' he said. Thousands of people gathered Tuesday in Vilnius, Lithuania's capital, for a rally in support of the regional party's move, said Lithuanian Radio editor Eduardas Potasinskas. Brazauskas, in an interview with the Interfax news service published Tuesday, defended his party's decision as a ``step toward renewal of the party.'' ``The idea is to make sure that the public perceives it as a new political force with a new message,'' he said. Medvedev, however, said the Lithuanian party would end up ``crushed by separatist and nationalist forces'' without Moscow's support. Despite Gorbachev's bluster, Brazauskas and other Lithuanian party leaders maintain that the Soviet leader has shown understanding of their move.
